June 2020 Roundup

Posted on 29 Jun 2020

Books
Educated by Tara Westover (3.5/5)
A highly popular autobiography of Tara Westover’s childhood as the youngest of seven children in a survivalist Mormon family in Idaho, with parents who largely shunned hospitals, formal education, and society at large. It spans her early childhood with her siblings helping her mother, an herbalist and midwife, and father, who worked in a junkyard. As a child she and her siblings were exposed to their father’s extreme fundamentalist Mormon doctrine, and also to highly dangerous conditions while aiding their father’s business. The book details the physical and psychological abuse Tara and her siblings faced from her elder brother Shawn (a pseudonym), and the tearing apart of her family that this abuse resulted in. Tara, following the example of her brother Tyler, miraculously self-studies well enough in the span of a couple years to propel herself into BYU, then Cambridge.

There are some aspects of the book that I find hard to believe. Her parents are difficult figures to understand, at times loving and supportive of college, but generally painted in broad and unsympathetic strokes (understandably, given the tension between Tara and her parents). Like others, I do suspect some elements of Tara’s quick propulsion to education to be exaggerated, although it is not really my place to judge.

Overall, I can see why the book was a quick and dramatic crowd-pleaser, and it depicted a successful image of physical and psychological abuse. I just think that other parts of the book should be taken with a grain of salt.
The Yellow House by Sarah M Broom (4/5)
This book is a well written, highly personal memoir of a house and its family, and the winner of the 2019 National Book Award for Nonfiction. It is quite deserving of that title. The Yellow House, located in New Orleans East, was purchased by Ivory Mae, the author Sarah's mother, where she eventually raised a total of 12 children.

This is a social history of how the house centered this family, and how the Water (Hurricane Katrina) scattered its members. It deals with the relations of New Orleans East to the rest of the city, the right to ownership of a place and a house, the meaning of such ownership, and the act of trying to remember from a past that was collectively but not personally experienced. Sarah writes of the efforts she goes through to piece together her father, who died shortly after she was born. She ponders over the push-and-pull relationship she and her family feel towards New Orleans, particularly after the Water; her quest to find her roots and takes her to Burundi and to the French Quarter, the touristy part of the city.
Who has the rights to the story of a place? Are these rights earned, bought, fought and died for? Or are they given? Are they automatic, like an assumption? Self-renewing? Are these rights a token of citizenship belonging to those who stay in the place or to those who leave and come back to it? Does the act of leaving relinquish one’s rights to the story of a place? Who stays gone? Who can afford to return?
The book successfully broaches themes of inequality and internalized shame. Sarah comments on the history of New Orleans and its relationship with New Orleans East, the predominantly black and working-class suburb of the city, and how the city dealt with its people after the hurricane.

There are so many things to love about this memoir. It can be a slower read for those who have no investment in or relation to New Orleans, but is still worth a read nonetheless. To me, the best parts of the story were those spent with the members of Broom's family, who were so intimately and colorfully described.
Hidden Valley Road: Inside the Mind of An American Family by Robert Kolker (5/5)
